title: Groupon to Exit Goods Market, Focus on 'Local Experiences'
summary: In 2019, goods accounted for about $1.12 billion, or slightly more than half Groupon's total revenue. Groupon Inc. said it planned to stop selling merchandise by the end of the year, driven out by what it called "a fiercely competitive, and in some cases, economically irrational retail landscape."

title: Pier 1 Imports Gets Approval for Bankruptcy Sale Process
summary: Troubled home-decor retailer is looking for bidders to buy all or some of its assets. Pier 1 Imports Inc. won court approval for a speedy sale process a day after the retailer tumbled into bankruptcy following a failed yearlong effort to reach a takeover deal with its lenders.

title: Bloomberg Proposals Would Stiffen Wall Street Oversight
summary: Proposals position the Democratic presidential candidate closer to his primary rivals. WASHINGTON-Presidential candidate Michael Bloomberg unveiled a raft of proposals to strengthen oversight of lenders, protect consumers and make college more affordable, a move that positions the billionaire former New York City mayor closer to the rest of the Democratic field on financial policy.

title: Blue Apron Eyes Options Including a Sale
summary: Meal-kit maker has shed customers and racked up losses as competition increased. Blue Apron Holdings Inc. said it is exploring strategic options including putting itself up for sale, after the meal-kit maker reported more customer defections and another quarterly loss.

title: Hockey Players Want to Block Planned Central Park Rink Changes
summary: Renovations to Lasker Rink and Pool would change the configuration of the ice rink and cut the size of the pool by 25%. Swimmers and hockey players are urging the private conservancy that maintains Manhattan's Central Park to reconsider a proposed $150 million renovation for Lasker Rink and Pool, saying some of their space will be removed.

title: U.S. Sanctions Subsidiary of Rosneft Over Alleged Venezuela Oil Exports
summary: More sanctions under consideration targeting foreign firms aiding Maduro regime. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration on Tuesday stepped up its pressure campaign against the Maduro regime in Venezuela by blacklisting the trading brokerage owned by Russia oil giant Rosneft that the U.S. says has been helping Caracas export crude.

title: How Bloomberg and Sanders Made Their Fortunes
summary: Comparing Mike's billions to Bernie's millions.. Michael Bloomberg is a lot wealthier than Bernie Sanders. But there's a case to be made that Mr. Sanders has been more creative in developing his business model. Who would have guessed that being a full-time socialist in the United States could result in a net worth more than 25 times that of the median American household?

title: Italy's Intesa Bids for Rival, Paving Way for Rare European Banking Deal
summary: Italian lender's $5.3 billion offer comes as a surprise amid European banks' resistance to consolidation. ROME-Italian bank Intesa Sanpaolo SpA has launched a €4.9 billion ($5.3 billion) takeover bid for a smaller rival, a move that would see the creation of the country's largest bank and could usher in a phase of long-waited consolidation in Europe.

title: Nike's New CEO Shuffles Executive Ranks
summary: Two longtime executives, Eric Sprunk and Elliott Hill, will leave in a shakeup. Nike Inc.'s new chief executive officer, John Donahoe, is shuffling the sportswear company's leadership ranks, a shake-up that will result in the departure of two longtime executives.

title: Unhappy With Seoul's Approach to North Korea, Defectors Run for Office
summary: Two prominent defectors are running for a conservative party in a legislative race they hope will reset Seoul's policy on Pyongyang. SEOUL-Growing up in Kim Jong Il's North Korea, Ji Seong-ho had no exposure to democracy. His first taste came in 2007 when he saw a presidential candidate give a speech at a local market, a year after the double-amputee escaped to South Korea using homemade crutches.

title: Euro Extends Decline on Weak German Data
summary: The euro was trading at its lowest level against the greenback since April 2017. The euro ticked lower against the dollar to trade at near its lowest level in almost three years after a measure of economic expectations in Germany dropped.

title: New Jersey Governor Proposes Antiharassment Legislation
summary: Law would allow domestic workers and unpaid interns to file discrimination lawsuits, extend statue of limitations, more. New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy is proposing legislation to better protect workers from harassment and discrimination, even as he defends against allegations about his own campaign.

title: Photos: Men Who Received Clemency From Trump
summary: Michael Milken, Rod Blagojevich, Edward DeBartolo Jr., Bernard Kerik. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: An Overstuffed 'Swan Lake' and Clarion 'Voices'
summary: Peter Martins's staging of the classic is an exercise in too-muchness; Alexei Ratmansky's premiere offers dancers and dancing in a fresh, oddball light..

title: China Plays Are Left Behind as U.S. Stocks Charge to New Highs
summary: S&P 500 keeps rising, but U.S.-listed Chinese companies and American firms with heavy exposure to China haven't gotten the same bump. U.S. stocks have hit repeated highs this year, but many China-related trades still lag behind the broader market.

title: 'Vida Americana: Mexican Muralists Remake American Art, 1925-1945' Review: Ideas Without Borders
summary: An illuminating show at the Whitney examines the impact of Mexican muralists on a wide spectrum of American artists.. New York

title: Sanders Leads Democratic Primary Field, WSJ/NBC News Poll Finds
summary: Four candidates essentially tied for second place, while President Trump's approval hits higher marks. Sen. Bernie Sanders has taken sole possession of the lead in the Democratic primary race, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds, with four candidates essentially tied for second place amid declining support for former Vice President Joe Biden and the rising profile of Michael Bloomberg, the former New York mayor.

title: DuPont CFO Likely to Focus on Cutting Costs, Regaining Investor Confidence
summary: Lori Koch's appointment comes as part of a wider management shuffle. DuPont de Nemours Inc.'s new finance chief is expected to help the industrial-materials maker cut costs and regain investor confidence as it faces weaker demand in some of its markets.

title: Huawei Suit Against U.S. Ban Is Dismissed
summary: A U.S. law bars agencies from doing business with the Chinese company. A federal judge in Texas dismissed a lawsuit filed by Huawei Technologies Co. challenging a 2018 U.S. law that stopped federal agencies from doing business with the Chinese company.

title: More Rain Expected as Mississippi Capital Floods
summary: Water levels will remain steady through Tuesday but will begin to fall through the week. More rain and flooding are expected in Mississippi's state capital this week, after the Pearl River crested near record heights over the holiday weekend.

title: U.K. Financial Watchdog Warns of Poor Compliance at Payments Firms
summary: Financial Conduct Authority has increased its scrutiny of firms that offer digital wallets out of concern about risks to consumers, the agency said Tuesday. A top financial regulator in the U.K. has stepped up its supervision of digital payments firms because of what it views as the industry's record of poor compliance and weak protections.

title: HQ Trivia Signals It Might Return
summary: Once-popular quiz app was beset by technical glitches, fundraising problems, death of executive. Live game-show app HQ Trivia shut down over the weekend, with hosts making profanity-laced comments and joking about unemployment on a final broadcast. But in an about-face Tuesday, the company's co-founder now says the quiz show might live on.

title: Former Law Firm Client Pleads Guilty in Panama Papers Case
summary: Harald Joachim von der Goltz is the first to plead guilty in the U.S. in connection with an investigation sparked by documents leaked from Mossack Fonseca. A former client of the law firm Mossack Fonseca on Tuesday became the first individual to plead guilty in the U.S. to charges stemming from a trove of leaked documents that became known as the Panama Papers.

title: DuPont Replaces CEO Amid Struggle to Expand Sales
summary: Edward Breen, architect of merger and three-way split, will work to rejuvenate materials maker. DuPont de Nemours Inc. said Tuesday that it is bringing back as its chief executive Edward D. Breen, an architect of the megamerger and spinoff from Dow Inc. that left a smaller industrial-materials maker struggling to generate sales growth.

title: Businessman Detained Anew After Turkish Court Acquits Him of Plotting to Oust Erdogan
summary: Osman Kavala, cleared on 2013 protests, is jailed further amid probe of possible role in failed 2016 coup. SILIVRI, Turkey-A Turkish court acquitted a prominent businessman who faced the prospect of a life prison sentence for allegedly colluding to overthrow President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's government in 2013, a surprise ruling that elicited long applause in the courtroom and impromptu celebrations in Istanbul.

title: Apple's Virus Warning Takes Bite Out of Chip-Maker Stocks
summary: The technology sector is likely to face some of the biggest disruptions from the outbreak due to the concentration of production in China. Semiconductor stocks slid Tuesday, pummeled by Apple Inc.'s warning that its revenue would be hurt by China's coronavirus outbreak.

title: U.S. Stocks Fall After Apple's Sales Warning
summary: Apple shares drop after company says it won't meet revenue projections because of coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped Tuesday after Apple warned its revenue may be lower than forecast due to the coronavirus in China, one of the most significant indications yet of the outbreak's impact on multinational businesses.

title: Amid Coronavirus, the World Closes Its Doors to China: 'I Feel So Isolated'
summary: Canceled flights and quarantines thwart China's ambitions to put the country at the center of commerce and culture. SHANGHAI-To celebrate Christmas one year, Jing Sun trekked to the North Pole to see reindeer. For another holiday, the Shenzhen native flew to Marrakesh, and she was recently in Cleveland for work. Los Angeles, New York and Barcelona were on her spring itinerary, while her maiden Australia voyage was penciled in.

title: HSBC Plans to Cut 35,000 Jobs, $100 Billion of Assets
summary: Europe's biggest bank plans to invest more in its fast-growing Asian and Middle Eastern operations. LONDON- HSBC Holdings PLC said it would shed 35,000 jobs and cut business lines and customer relationships across the U.S. and Europe, the latest phase in a decade long retreat from global ambitions to focus on its Asian heartland.

title: Canada Loosens Mortgage-Financing Rules
summary: The government is lowering the minimum rate used to determine whether a buyer can afford principal and interest payments if rates climb. OTTAWA-Canada loosened mortgage-financing rules originally introduced to keep house prices in check and deter debt growth, marking a shift in policy after fears of a U.S.-style housing bubble over the last decade.

title: North Carolina Appeals Court Puts Voter ID Requirement on Hold
summary: Ruling adds new hurdle for identification requirement ahead of 2020 election. A North Carolina appeals court temporarily blocked a state voter-identification law while saying the measure was discriminatory, raising a new hurdle for Republican proponents who have pushed for requiring ID at the polls.

title: Bed Bath & Beyond Boss Tries to Declutter Stores
summary: In search of solution to 'purchase paralysis,' new CEO will cut number of items, widen aisles. Bed Bath & Beyond Inc.'s new chief executive, Mark Tritton, laid out his vision for remaking the troubled retailer. Decluttering stores is high on his list.

title: Franklin Resources to Buy Legg Mason for $4.5 Billion
summary: Deal would clear up uncertainty that had shrouded Legg Mason's future for nearly a year. Franklin Resources Inc. agreed to buy rival asset manager Legg Mason Inc. for $4.5 billion in cash, a deal that could help two big players in an industry that is under pressure from shifting investor tastes.

title: Palladium Prices Hit Record Despite Chinese Auto Disruption
summary: Demand for the precious metal has surged as auto regulators tighten emissions regulations in China and Europe. Palladium prices soared Tuesday despite shutdowns and delays at car plants in China, the world's biggest consumer of the precious metal, highlighting an extended spell of volatility in the commodity's market.

title: New York Ties a Rise in Stop-and-Frisk to Better Reporting
summary: Total for 2019 was up 22% to 13,459, but still far below the high of 685,724 in 2011 under then-Mayor Michael Bloomberg. An increase in reports of stop-and-frisk by the New York City Police Department last year after years of decline was due to better record-keeping, law enforcement officials said.

title: Susan Collins Faces Tough Re-Election Race in Maine, Poll Suggests
summary: Survey shows her slightly behind expected Democratic rival in November race. WASHINGTON-The polarized political climate is taking a toll on Sen. Susan Collins (R., Maine), who is facing a competitive race for the first time since she won a Senate seat in 1996, according to a new poll conducted after her closely watched votes in President Trump's Senate impeachment trial.

title: Glencore Swings to Loss Amid Lower Commodity Prices
summary: Anglo-Swiss commodity company booked $2.8 billion in impairments, driven by a steep drop in thermal-coal prices. Glencore PLC swung to a loss in 2019 as subdued prices for commodities-including coal-weighed on earnings in its industrial unit and prompted the miner to write down the value of key assets.

title: Bombardier Shed Snowmobiles for Jets, Trains. Now, It's Giving Up Both.
summary: 'Things were piling one on top of the other, it was a very tough situation,' says CEO Alain Bellmare. TORONTO- Bombardier Inc. tried to take on much bigger players in the global market for trains and commercial jetliners. Having shed both those businesses in as many weeks, it now plans to pare the debt that forced those retreats, and navigate a much smaller industry: business jets.

title: Walmart Posts Mixed Holiday Sales
summary: Retailer books strong online sales but cites weakness in U.S. stores. Walmart Inc. reported sluggish holiday sales despite continued online gains, adding to a string of disappointments from traditional retailers as they adjust to changing shopping habits.

title: Beware Engineers-and Other Business Lessons of Presidential History
summary: Business and presidential elections don't always mix well.. Editor's note: This is an excerpt from our newsletter, "2020 Election+Business," a weekly dive into the intersection of business, finance and the 2020 election. You can sign up here.

title: Commentary: Supply-Chain Risks From the Coronavirus Demand Immediate Action
summary: MIT's Yossi Sheffi writes that the unknown potential impact of the virus shouldn't stop companies from acting quickly to minimize short- and long-term impact on their operations. As scientists race to develop a cure for the coronavirus, businesses are trying to assess the impact of the outbreak on their own enterprises. Just as scientists are confronting an unknown enemy, corporate executives are largely working blind because the coronavirus could cause supply-chain disruptions that are unlike anything we have seen in the past 70 years.

title: Trump Pardons Former 49ers Owner DeBartolo
summary: DeBartolo pleaded guilty in 1998 to failing to report a felony related to an investigation into the Louisiana gaming industry. WASHINGTON-President Trump has pardoned Edward DeBartolo Jr., a former owner of the San Francisco 49ers, who pleaded guilty to a felony in 1998 as part of a Louisiana gambling-industry investigation.

title: Administration Plans to Waive Laws to Speed Wall Construction
summary: Homeland Security to drop restrictions on open competition for federal contracts, among others. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is planning to waive some federal contracting laws to accelerate construction of its southern-border wall, according to a notice filed Tuesday by the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Some New York Lawmakers Push Mobile Betting Amid Budget Deficit
summary: New Yorkers are placing bets on sports events in New Jersey. For some legislators, that's lost tax revenue.. ALBANY, N.Y.-As state lawmakers debate whether to legalize mobile sports betting in the Empire State, New Yorkers wagered $837 million on sporting events in New Jersey last year, according to an industry-funded study released Tuesday.

title: Hey, Taxman, Leave Those Kids Alone
summary: An overzealous IRS has changed its tune on in-game currency. Quit playing games and do your taxes!

title: Afghanistan Confirms Ashraf Ghani Has Won Second Term as President
summary: Loser vows to form a parallel government, threatening political unrest amid U.S. efforts to reach peace deal with Taliban. KABUL-Afghanistan's President Ashraf Ghani has won a second term in office with a slim majority of the votes cast, a result that comes five months after the election and threatens to spark political unrest amid U.S. efforts to reach a peace deal with the Taliban.

title: PG&E Reports $3.6 Billion Quarterly Loss as Wildfire Costs Mount
summary: Utility lost $7.7 billion in 2019 and says it is on track to exit bankruptcy in mid-2020. PG&E Corp. reported a $3.6 billion fourth-quarter loss as it continued to settle investigations and claims related to California wildfires.

title: Dutch Court Reinstates Order for Russia to Pay Yukos Shareholders
summary: Putin critic and former Yukos chief Khodorkovsky says verdict shows state's seizure of oil company was political. MOSCOW-A Dutch court Tuesday reinstated an order that Russia pay $50 billion in compensation to shareholders of former Russian oil giant Yukos, which was once headed by Mikhail Khodorkovsky, a vocal critic of President Vladimir Putin.

title: Plastic Bags Help the Environment
summary: Banning them provides no benefit other than to let activists lord their preferences over others.. Why do politicians want to take away our plastic bags and straws? This moral panic is intensifying even as evidence mounts that banning plastic is both a waste of money and harmful to the environment. If you want to protect dolphins and sea turtles, you should take special care to place your plastic in the trash, not the recycling bin. And if you're worried about climate change, you'll cherish those gossamer grocery bags once you learn the facts about plastic.

title: Sanofi to Work on Virus Vaccine
summary: French drug giant is reviving research prompted by SARS epidemic. Drug giant Sanofi SA has entered the race to develop a vaccine against the new coronavirus, joining a handful of big and small drug makers, and teams of university researchers, looking for a way to prevent its spread.

title: These Commuters Stretch Daily Grind Far Beyond 9 to 5
summary: Podcasts, audio books and meditation: Workers keep travel to and from the office as productive as possible. Some New Yorkers spend their morning train ride playing "Candy Crush" or trying to doze. Then there is Natalie Jaeger, master of the productive commute. "In a city as busy as New York City, every moment counts," she says.

title: U.K. Regulator Urges Companies to Report Coronavirus Risks
summary: The Financial Reporting Council says companies and auditors should provide up-to-date information related to coronavirus in year-end results. The U.K.'s audit and accounting watchdog said Tuesday that companies and auditors should provide up-to-date information on the risks arising from the novel coronavirus when reporting their year-end results.

title: China's Real-Estate Market Is Coronavirus Latest Victim
summary: Growth in home prices at lowest level since July 2018 and expected to weaken further. BEIJING-China's home-price growth slowed to an 18-month low in January, but it looks set to fall a lot further as Beijing's long-running attempts to rein in the property market meet with effects from the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Rick Singer Didn't Make Any Parents Cheat
summary: One of the kids who was hurt is my friend's daughter who, despite significantly higher credentials than Mr. Hodge's kids had, was unable to get into a "great school" because his kids took the spot.. In Doug Hodge's apology "I Wish I'd Never Met Rick Singer" (op-ed, Feb. 10) is his statement: "Today I realize that what I did was not only wrong but immoral, and it hurt others."

title: 'The Fashion Police' Used to Be a Funny Joke
summary: Banning politically incorrect products is beyond the New York City Commission on Human Rights's authority.. New York City's Commission on Human Rights is threatening free expression in the fashion industry ("Prada and the New Fashion Police," Review & Outlook, Feb. 8).

title: Baltimore's Black Voters Control Its Future
summary: Only Baltimore's black majority has the voting power to bring in a new political team that will not keep running the city into the ground.. As a born and bred Baltimorean who still loves the Charm City, I found Sean Kennedy's "'The Wire' Is Finished, but Baltimore Still Bleeds" (Cross Country, Feb. 8) heartbreaking, but unsurprising. Baltimore's soaring murder rate, even as the city's population shrinks, is a manifestation of general decay from the inside of City Hall out to crime-infested neighborhoods that border wealthier suburbs.

title: The Progressively Purer Left Will Need a Smaller Tent
summary: Bobby Jindal argues that Democrats have adopted rigid, religious-type views on climate, abortion and gender fluidity. I'd add: open borders, identity politics, free stuff, high taxes and evil President Trump, among others.. Bobby Jindal ("Democrats Want a Prophet, Not a President," op-ed, Feb. 11) argues that Democrats have adopted rigid, religious-type views on climate, abortion and gender fluidity. I might add to Mr. Jindal's list: open borders, identity politics, free stuff, high taxes and evil President Trump, among others. As the Democratic moral purity tests become more numerous, it will be increasingly tough to have a large tent.

title: Producer Andrew Watt Returns to Rock 'n' Roll on Ozzy Osbourne's Latest Album
summary: After writing hits for Justin Bieber and Cardi B, the guitarist and producer mines his musical roots. Andrew Watt, a music producer, called Red Hot Chili Peppers drummer Chad Smith and Guns N' Roses bassist Duff McKagan-with whom he'd recently played Van Halen songs at a charity event-and invited them to his home studio in Beverly Hills to make an Ozzy Osbourne album. Over four days last fall, Mr. Watt said, they wrote and recorded most of "Ordinary Man," Mr. Osbourne's first solo album in 10 years, which comes out Friday.

title: Samsung Galaxy by Thom Browne: Why 'Designer Cell Phone' Is No Longer a Punchline
summary: Last week's debut of limited edition Samsung Galaxy Z Flip in partnership with American fashion designer Thom Browne reflects how more consumers are now viewing cell phones as a luxury item. LAST WEDNESDAY, as an unexpected capstone to New York Fashion Week, designer Thom Browne presented not a new clothing collection, but a new cell phone. It was, to be precise, his customization of the Samsung Galaxy Z Flip phone, the ballyhooed first "foldable glass" phone that the Korean brand unveiled a day prior during its "Galaxy Unpacked" summit in San Francisco. This designer edition of the phone teems with details from Mr. Browne's whimsical world: A red, white and blue grosgrain stripe, echoing the ribbon on his dress shirts, wraps the case; app icons are customized to look like size labels; the phone opens with an animation of slatted Venetian blinds like those that envelop Mr. Browne's stores. For $2,480, the grayish phone, which went up for pre-order last Friday, comes bundled with a pair of similarly Browne-ified earbuds and a smartwatch.

title: An Italian Concept Car That Broke All Tradition
summary: Resume Subscription. Phillip Sarofim of Beverly Hills, Calif., 33, founder and partner of the venture-capital firm Trousdale Ventures, on his 1970 Lancia Stratos HF Zero, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: Autumn de Wilde Preferred Life Behind the Lens
summary: The 'Emma' director's British-American family moved and traveled often, and kept a wide circle of artistic friends. Autumn de Wilde, 49, is an American photographer, videographer and the director of "Emma," a film adaptation of the Jane Austen novel, opening Feb. 21. She spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Forget Dow 30K. It's Already Hit 40K on License Plates
summary: Nothing says stock-market bull like a vanity plate on a BMW. When the index reaches milestones, optimists post new predictions on bumpers. A 10,000-point rise for the Dow Jones Industrial Average isn't what it used to be.

title: Coronavirus Exposes Businesses' Dependency on China
summary: Apple's warning indicates the global impact as companies in China struggle to restart operations and combat worker shortages. Just as the U.S.-China trade war was starting to fade, the coronavirus crisis is exposing how heavily dependent foreign companies are on China for their production and business.

title: HSBC's Headless Restructuring Plan
summary: The board's decision to delay appointing a CEO leaves investors wondering about the plans to overhaul the bank. HSBC 's interim chief executive Noel Quinn announced a sweeping overhaul of the bank's business on Tuesday, but the board's decision to hold off on confirmation of a permanent role for him has left investors wondering about the restructuring.

title: Coronavirus Quarantine Criticized After More Passengers Infected
summary: As the two-week quarantine comes to an end Wednesday, number of infected passengers and crew on board the Diamond Princess passed 500. TOKYO-After decades as a primary-care doctor in Elizabethton, Tenn., Arnold Hopland thought he knew something about preventing infections. And the way they were doing a virus quarantine on the Diamond Princess cruise ship didn't look right.

title: Holding Breath and Waiting at Daytona
summary: A terrifying crash on the final lap of the Daytona 500 turns the public's concern to driver Ryan Newman. Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Iran Sentences Environmentalists, Including a U.S. Citizen, to Prison
summary: Jail terms come as tensions between Tehran and Washington continue to smolder. Iran sentenced eight environmentalists to lengthy prison sentences, most of them for allegedly colluding with the U.S., the latest crackdown on activists and dual nationals amid heightened tensions with the West and simmering unrest at home.

title: High Car Prices Are Locking Out Younger Shoppers
summary: As auto makers shift away from cheaper models, dealers lament losing first-time buyers. LAS VEGAS-Auto dealers want to lure young buyers back to new-car lots.

title: How Daniel M. Lavery Melds Trans Memoir With Sketch Humor
summary: The humor writer and advice columnist on infusing his transition memoir with satire, history and deep thoughts. Daniel M. Lavery's imaginings and fantasies have been bright spots on the Internet for quite a while. In 2013 he and fellow writer Nicole Cliffe founded the delightfully weird website The Toast. The site's spot-on literary fan fiction, twisted fairy tales and odes to hyper-specific pop cultural moments have become a hallmark of his work. (The site essentially ceased publication in 2016) In Lavery's latest collection of essays and interludes, Something That May Shock and Discredit You, he offers a whimsical Lord Byron parody, Mean Girls fanfic and a Steve Martin appreciation, and he also makes a solid case for why Duckie from Pretty in Pink is actually a lesbian.

title: Food-Delivery Firms Put Mergers, IPOs on the Menu
summary: DoorDash, Grubhub and others are weighing tie-ups or looking for funding. The biggest food-delivery companies in the U.S. are seeking to shore up their finances through mergers or public listings, according to executives in an industry that has generated rapid growth but spotty profits.

title: The Real Chinese Trade Spat Is About Engines, Not Soybeans
summary: The U.S. could block a GE venture's engine sales to China, showing that economic complexity is at the core of the conflict. The "phase one" deal signed between the U.S. and China in January fueled investors' hopes that disruptions to global supply chains were coming to an end. Instead, it may have marked the start of the real trade conflict.

title: Players Blast MLB Commissioner for Handling of Astros' Cheating Scandal
summary: The Angels' Mike Trout didn't agree with the lack of punishments for players, while the Dodgers' Justin Turner took exception to Rob Manfred calling the World Series trophy a 'piece of metal'. Spring training camps have been open for a week, and there may as well be billboards plastered along every highway across Florida and Arizona declaring open season on Major League Baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred.

title: Three Cell Tower Companies Become the Hottest Play in Real Estate
summary: With rollout of 5G networks and promise of self-driving cars, the value of towers is expected to rise. Cell towers, often considered a neighborhood eyesore in the minds of the public, look like money these days to real-estate investors.

title: Defaults Are Rising in Sluggish New York City Hotel Market
summary: Construction boom expands supply, knocking room rates down to their lowest point since 2013. More New York City hotel owners are defaulting on their mortgages, succumbing to a crush of new supply and rising expenses.

title: Are Floating Hotels, Office Buildings the Answer to Rising Sea Levels?
summary: More developers see waterborne structures as a way to alleviate housing shortages and to support temporary events like the 2022 soccer World Cup. A real-estate investor is building 16 hotels for the 2022 soccer World Cup in Qatar, but they won't be there for long. All of them will be floating on water.

title: Beijing's Soft Power Push on Global Tax
summary: The little-known tax drive associated with China's Belt and Road initiative could shape corporate tax rules around the world. China's trillion-dollar Belt and Road initiative to build infrastructure connecting Asia, Africa and Europe has generated plenty of headlines, but its tax arm remains little known. Companies and policy makers alike need to pay closer attention. The project could end up affecting how multinationals pay tax and resolve disputes around the globe.

title: Apple Isn't Priced for Sick Leave
summary: iPhone maker pulls its cheerful forecast for the current quarter-with its shares at the highest multiple in more than a decade. This isn't the first time Apple Inc. has misread the situation in China. It may prove to be the most costly, though.

title: Post-Impeachment Senate Landscape Takes Shape
summary: Democrats, Republicans hope to get a political boost from Trump trial, with each party tapping into energized bases and record fundraising. WASHINGTON-In the brewing battle for control of the U.S. Senate, both Democrats and Republicans hope to get a political boost from the impeachment trial of President Trump, with each side pointing to energized bases and record fundraising.

title: Winter Is Wildfire Prep Season in California
summary: Resume Subscription. WINDSOR, Calif.-Grass and other vegetation have begun to cover the ash left behind when the largest blaze of the 2019 wildfire season burned the edge of this Northern California town about four months ago.

title: Teens Delete Instagrams Nearly as Fast as They Post Them
summary: Regularly culling their feeds helps ensure teens are putting their best face forward and youthful transgressions don't come back to haunt them. For many teens who have been on social media since they were in the single digits, grappling with their emerging adulthood in real time is forcing them to take a hard look at how they present themselves. As a result, they are routinely culling their Instagram feeds and deleting posts just days or even hours after they go up.

title: Amazon Changes the Way It Recruits M.B.A.s

summary: Coronavirus outbreak threatens to delay any recovery in the world's largest car market. The coronavirus epidemic threatens to delay the budding recovery in the world's largest car market. Investors hoping for government support to speed it up, however, could be disappointed.

title: Boy Scouts Seek Chapter 11 Protection From Sex-Abuse Suits
summary: The 110-year-old youth organization filed for bankruptcy to cope with financial pressures from sex-abuse lawsuits and declining membership. The Boy Scouts of America on Tuesday filed for bankruptcy protection, as one of the country's largest youth organizations tries to endure intensifying legal pressure over accusations of childhood sexual abuse going back decades.

title: Gilead's Coronavirus Drug Trial Slowed by Lack of Eligible Recruits
summary: Patients in the test must not have taken other treatments within 30 days. BEIJING-Clinical trials being conducted in Wuhan to test Gilead Sciences Inc.'s antiviral drug, a promising remedy for the new coronavirus, are going more slowly than hoped for as the drugmaker struggles to recruit qualified patients, underscoring the challenges in quickly developing drugs during outbreaks.

title: Dell Nears Deal to Sell RSA Security Business to Private-Equity Firm STG
summary: Dell could announce a deal at more than $2 billion as soon as Tuesday. Dell Technologies Inc. is nearing a deal to sell its RSA cybersecurity business to a private-equity firm for more than $2 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Bolton Avoids Trump and Ukraine in Public Appearance
summary: President's former aide, who almost upended impeachment trial, reiterates criticisms of foreign policy toward Iran, North Korea. DURHAM, N.C.-More than 1,000 people gathered in a Duke University auditorium to find out whether John Bolton, President Trump's former national security adviser whose leaked manuscript threatened to upend the Senate impeachment trial last month, was finally ready to tell all.

title: You're Getting Married Again. Should You Combine Finances?
summary: Many experts say it's OK to keep things separate, as long as separate doesn't mean secret. For many people, the decision to remarry and combine households is fraught with all sorts of difficult questions. One of the toughest: Should we combine finances, too?

title: What 'Rothifying' 401(k)s Would Mean for Retirees
summary: Research shows that moving 401(k)s to after-tax contributions would boost tax returns in the short term, but leave retirees worse off. There's a lot of talk these days about overhauling the retirement-savings system. In Washington, much of the discussion centers on ways to give an immediate boost to government revenues by limiting retirement tax breaks.

title: Game Plan: A Musician/Podcaster Starts Thinking About Retirement
summary: John Roderick made $85,000 last year on his podcasts; a financial adviser suggests he set some goals. John Roderick has worked for himself his entire career, doing things many people dream about, like writing songs, playing in rock bands and hosting podcasts. Recently, the 51-year-old, who lives in Seattle, has begun to think seriously about retirement.

title: Game Plan: A Couple Wants to Pay Off Debt-and Save for Disney World
summary: An adviser suggests a plan for debt reduction, spending and saving for bucket-list items. As Freddie and Mary Ellen Fabbri near their 50s, they dream of bucket-list items like taking their 4-year-old daughter to Disney World

title: Mississippi Prepares for Damage From Receding Floodwaters
summary: The Pearl River appeared to peak Monday afternoon at around 36.8 feet. Floodwaters in central Mississippi approached record heights Monday, leaving hundreds of homes and businesses inundated and roads closed around the capital city of Jackson, according to state officials, who also warned of continued danger as the waters recede in the coming days.

title: U.S. Weighs New Move to Limit China's Access to Chip Technology
summary: Trump administration targets Huawei with proposed changes to restrict use of American chip-making equipment. The Trump administration is weighing new trade restrictions on China that would limit the use of American chip-making equipment, as it seeks to cut off Chinese access to key semiconductor technology, according to people familiar with the plan.

title: Growth Investors Face Test of Their Mettle
summary: Apple is the first major U.S. company to say it won't meet revenue projections due to the coronavirus outbreak. The revenue warning issued on Monday by Apple Inc. is another test of investors' long-running love affair with so-called growth stocks.

title: Missing From Harvey Weinstein Prosecution: Police Witnesses
summary: District attorneys didn't call detectives-as is typical -after allegations of faulty police work. A Manhattan jury will begin deliberating in Harvey Weinstein's rape trial Tuesday after prosecutors presented testimony from 28 people to support their case. Not one witness was a law-enforcement officer.

title: Alstom to Buy Bombardier Train Unit
summary: Deal valued at $8.2 billion, including debt, will create new, European-focused train giant. France's Alstom SA said it agreed to buy Bombardier Inc.'s train unit in a deal valued at $8.2 billion, including debt, infusing the Canadian industrial giant with much-needed cash and creating what would be a new, European-focused train giant big enough to take on China.

title: Tokyo Marathon Closes to Public Participants
summary: Nearly 30,000 runners are cut from the March 1 event, which only will accept elite entrants. TOKYO-The Tokyo Marathon closed itself to public entries because of the coronavirus outbreak, cutting more than 30,000 runners less than two weeks before the event.

title: Apple to Fall Short of Projected Revenue Due to Coronavirus
summary: Tech giant says iPhone supply will be constrained. Apple Inc. became the first major U.S. company to say it won't meet its revenue projections for the current quarter due to the coronavirus outbreak, which it said had limited iPhone production for world-wide sales and curtailed demand for its products in China.

title: Ban on Assault-Style Weapons Blocked in Virginia Senate
summary: Senate committee delays measure sought by Democratic leaders until next year. A Virginia Senate committee dealt a blow to a top legislative priority for the state's new Democratic legislative majority, voting Monday to delay a bill banning the sale of assault-style weapons.
